description: NPR's Up First is the news you need to start your day. The three biggest stories of the day, with reporting and analysis from NPR News — in 10 minutes. Available weekdays by 6 a.m. ET, with hosts Leila Fadel, Steve Inskeep, Rachel Martin and A Martinez. Also available on Saturdays by 8 a.m. ET, with Scott Simon. On Sundays, hear a longer exploration behind the headlines with Rachel Martin, available by 8 a.m. ET. Subscribe and listen, then support your local NPR station at donate.npr.org.

items.content: Russia agreed to a short cease fire for two cities in Ukraine's south to allow civilians to leave, but evacuations were stopped because fighting continued. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is in neighboring Poland to discuss additional security measures and to meet refugees. The Biden administration is hesitant to halt oil imports from Russia.

itunes.summary: Russia agreed to a short cease fire for two cities in Ukraine's south to allow civilians to leave, but evacuations were stopped because fighting continued. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is in neighboring Poland to discuss additional security measures and to meet refugees. The Biden administration is hesitant to halt oil imports from Russia.

items.title: Saturday, March 5, 2022

items.content: A fire at a Ukrainian nuclear plant has put Europe on alert. Russia now controls the facility, and the fire is out. How safe are Ukraine's other nuclear plants? Russia continues its indiscriminate attacks on Ukrainian cities. Thousands of people are believed to have been killed or wounded, and the country's economy has changed overnight. And in the first trial connected to the January 6 attack on the Capitol, a son testified against his father. Guy Reffitt was bragging about the attack when his son Jackson secretly recorded him and turned him in.

items.title: Friday, March 4, 2022

items.content: More than 1 million people have fled Ukraine since the start of Russia's invasion. Russia says it has captured the first Ukrainian city as troops continue their attacks. What is Russia's military strategy? Former President Donald Trump broke the law. That's according to a new court filing by the House panel investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. And the White House's new COVID strategy involves a new system for treatment and surveillance.

items.title: Thursday, March 3, 2022

items.content: We have three stories of democracy on this Wednesday morning. One in Texas, where Americans voted. One in Washington, where President Biden delivered the state of the Union. And one in Ukraine, where an elected government remains in power. The president of Ukraine called on Russia to stop bombing civilian areas. The president of the United States promised support and addressed problems at home. And Greg Abbott, the Republican governor of Texas has his challenger. Beto O'Rourke won Tuesday's Democratic primary.

items.title: Wednesday, March 2, 2022

items.content: A 40-mile convoy of Russian military vehicles is heading toward Ukraine's capital. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, meanwhile, signed an application for EU membership. What are the side effects of sanctions on Russia? No country this large and powerful has ever faced quite so much economic pressure. And President Biden will address the nation tonight in his first State of the Union. Can he convince Americans he's got things under control?

items.title: Tuesday, March 1, 2022

items.content: Europeans isolate Russia, arm Ukraine, and start to rearm themselves. Ukrainian forces still hold their capital Kyiv. And the Ukrainian government is sending representatives to Belarus to talk with Russia. How does Putin respond to this increased pressure? At a border crossing to Poland, women and children flee, while men stay to fight. Also, Germany's leader called for more defense spending. How does he see the continent's future security?

items.title: Monday, February 28, 2022
